content.label: Essential Question
content.question:
How can combining investments that behave differently
reduce your risk without sacrificing returns?

objectives.description: Understand how diversification reduces portfolio risk through correlation principles between different assets.
Build balanced investment portfolios using appropriate asset allocation strategies based on age and goals.
Assess the relationship between portfolio diversification and expected returns vs. potential losses.
Use rebalancing strategies to maintain target asset allocation over time and stay disciplined.

terms.definition: Spreading investments across different assets, sectors, and geographies to reduce risk by avoiding overexposure.
terms.example: Owning stocks, bonds, real estate, and international funds instead of just one company's stock.

terms.definition: The degree to which two investments move together. +1.0 = lockstep, -1.0 = opposite directions, 0 = independent.
terms.example: Low correlation between assets means when one drops, the other may rise‚Äîreducing overall volatility.

terms.definition: The percentage breakdown of your portfolio across major asset classes (stocks, bonds, real estate, cash).
terms.example: Asset allocation determines ~90% of portfolio behavior‚Äîmore important than individual stock picks!

terms.definition: Periodically adjusting your portfolio back to target allocations by selling overweight assets and buying underweight ones.
terms.example: Forces you to "buy low, sell high" automatically‚Äîselling winners at peaks, buying losers at lows.

leftPanel.title: How Combining Assets Reduces Risk
paragraphs: When you own two investments that don't move in perfect lockstep, you create a stabilizing effect.
Example: You have $10,000. Tech Stock X drops 40%, but Healthcare Stock Y rises 10%. If split equally:

‚Ä¢ $5,000 √ó -40% = -$2,000
‚Ä¢ $5,000 √ó +10% = +$500
‚Ä¢ Net loss: Only 15% instead of 40%!

highlightBox.text: � By combining uncorrelated assets, you keep most upside potential while dramatically cutting downside risk.

stats.label: Stocks to Eliminate Most Company Risk

leftPanel.title: How Different Assets Behave
paragraphs: Stocks: 10% avg returns, 30-40% swings. Growth engine with volatility.
Bonds: 3-6% returns, low volatility. Often rise when stocks fall (negative correlation).
Real Estate (REITs): Moderate correlation with stocks (~0.5), income + inflation hedge.
Gold/Commodities: Very low correlation with stocks. Crisis hedge.

highlightBox.text: � Combining assets with LOW correlation to each other = maximum diversification benefit.

layoutData.title: The "120 Minus Your Age" Rule
paragraphs: Your age determines how much volatility you can afford. Young investors have decades to recover from crashes; retirees don't. A common guideline: 120 minus your age = stock percentage.
bulletPoints: Age 25 (95% stocks): Maximum growth focus. 40-year recovery time. Accept 35-40% crash risk.
Age 45 (75% stocks): Balanced approach. Building wealth while adding stability.
Age 60 (60% stocks): Preservation priority. Can't afford massive losses before retirement.
Age 70 (50% stocks): Income focus. Steady withdrawals need steady portfolio.

keyPoint.text: üìà Being too conservative when young costs more than being too aggressive‚Äîyou miss decades of compound growth!

leftPanel.title: Automatic "Buy Low, Sell High"
paragraphs: Without rebalancing: After stocks surge, you're taking more risk than planned. After crashes, less.
Example:

‚Ä¢ Start: $70K stocks / $30K bonds (70/30)
‚Ä¢ After stock rise: $84K stocks / $31K bonds (73/27)
‚Ä¢ Rebalance: Sell $3.5K stocks, buy bonds
‚Ä¢ Result: Back to 70/30, profits locked in!

highlightBox.text: ‚ö° Rebalancing forces discipline: sell winners at highs, buy losers at lows‚Äîemotionlessly!

layoutData.title: The Real Power: Staying Invested
paragraphs: Diversification's true value isn't just reducing volatility‚Äîit's enabling you to stay invested through crashes instead of panic-selling and locking in losses.
bulletPoints: Diversified investors: See 20-25% drops, feel uncomfortable but manageable. Stay invested. Capture recovery.
Concentrated investors: See 50-70% drops, feel terror. Panic sell at bottom. Miss recovery entirely.
Real-world data: Average investor earns 3-5% vs. market's 10% due to emotional buying/selling.
The math: $500/month at 8% for 30 years = $680K. At 3% (panic selling) = $290K. Diversification = $390K saved!

keyPoint.text: üí∞ Diversification makes crashes survivable, which is how you actually achieve long-term market returns.

leftPanel.title: One Fund, Complete Diversification
paragraphs: Target-date funds (e.g., "Target 2060 Fund") automatically handle everything:
‚Ä¢ Diversification: Holds US stocks, international stocks, bonds, sometimes REITs
‚Ä¢ Age-based allocation: Starts aggressive (90% stocks), gradually shifts conservative
‚Ä¢ Automatic rebalancing: No manual work required
‚Ä¢ One decision: Pick the year closest to your retirement

highlightBox.text: � Perfect for investors who want professional-level diversification without managing it themselves.

scenario.name: Aaliyah's Target-Date Success
paragraphs: At 24, Aaliyah started her first job and chose a Target 2060 Fund for her 401(k), contributing $400/month. She never changed her allocation‚Äîthe fund handled everything automatically.
When the market crashed 35% at age 32, she kept contributing monthly, automatically buying stocks at depressed prices. The fund rebalanced, selling some bonds to buy more stocks on sale.
By age 39, her $95,000 in contributions had grown to $142,000‚Äîon track for $2.1 million by retirement.

scenario.name: Destiny's Costly Concentration
paragraphs: At 28, Destiny invested her $25,000 savings entirely in tech stocks and Bitcoin, convinced diversification was "outdated advice." For three years, she seemed brilliant‚Äîher portfolio surged to $95,000.
Then tech crashed 60%. Her portfolio plummeted to $38,000. Psychologically devastated, she panic-sold at the bottom, locking in losses.
Her diversified friend Jordan had only grown to $42K, then dropped to $35K‚Äîbut stayed invested and recovered. By age 35: Jordan had $74K, Destiny had $40K in cash.

content.question:
Why did Aaliyah's "boring" target-date fund strategy
outperform Destiny's "exciting" concentrated approach?

What role did psychology play in the outcomes?

If you saw your portfolio drop 40%, would you be able to stay invested?

What allocation would make crashes manageable enough
that you wouldn't panic sell?

takeaways.title: Correlation Is Key
takeaways.description: Combine assets that move differently‚Äîstocks + bonds, US + international‚Äîto reduce risk without sacrificing returns

takeaways.title: Age Drives Allocation
takeaways.description: Young investors should be aggressive (90% stocks); shift conservative as retirement nears to protect accumulated wealth

takeaways.title: Rebalance Annually
takeaways.description: Restore target allocations once per year to maintain risk level and force disciplined "buy low, sell high" behavior

takeaways.title: Survive to Thrive
takeaways.description: Diversification's true power is enabling you to stay invested through crashes instead of panic-selling at the worst time
